Description: Bronze model axe-head with original wooden haft: the blade was made of thin sheet metal. It has a straight butt, lightly incurved sides, and a moderately convex cutting edge. The butt is considerably wider than the cutting edge. The lugs are angular and the corners of the cutting edge rounded. The blade is lightly corroded in parts. Chased on one face is a hieroglyphic inscription. It is moderately corroded on both faces. The accompanying haft is badly chipped and broken at the bottom. None of the original binding survives but the haft is discoloured around the socket.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Temple of Thutmose III, foundation deposit
Curator's comments: Bibliography: E. A. Wallis Budge 'A Guide to the Fourth, Fifth and Sixth Egyptian Rooms, and the Coptic Room' (London, 1922), 202, 32; J. Morris Weinstein, 'Foundation Deposits in Ancient Egypt' (Pennsylvania, 1973 [Dissertation]), 188 (3); B. Porter & R. Moss, 'Topographical Bibliography of Ancient Egyptian Hieroglyphic Texts, Reliefs and Paintings' II (2) (Oxford, 1974), p.381.
Bibliographic references: Davies 1987 / Catalogue of Egyptian Antiquities in the British Museum (118)
Condition: broken into two pieces EA 55258, fragment of a wooden handle, appears to join the broken end of the handle of EA 6059.
Associated names: Named in inscription: Thutmose III (as Menkheperra)
